Line 15: Line 15:
==History==
==History==
=== Conception ===
=== Conception ===
â
[[File:Bbc2two.jpg|thumb|left|The predecessor of the 1991-1997 idents (colloquially called the "TWO" due to being BBC Two's only identity to show the number [[2 (number)|2]] as a word than a digit) was criticized by many viewers, calling it 'dull' and 'worthy'.<ref>http://thetvroom.com/bbc-uk/bbc-2-11-01.html</ref>]]
+
{{quote box |width=30em | bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |align=left|quote="I realized there was a problem almost as soon as I took over the channel [BBC2]. It was obvious that the logo [TWO] made absolutely no impact. In fact, it was something anyone could have told you. It was singularly unmemorable, and told you nothing about the personality of the channel. So we decided to commission a corporate design company to do some research."|salign=right |source=Alan Yentob<ref name="HDTDT">[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GbpITaGT4-8 YouTube: BBC2 1991-2001 Idents / How Do They Do That?]</ref>}}
â
Origins of the 1991-1997 idents (and the subsequent 1997-2001 idents) trace back to the unpopularity of its predecessor; A [[wordmark]] of the number [[2 (number)|2]] stylized as "TWO", coloured with red, green and blue within a white background (leaving the 'O' uncoloured). Designed by [[Alan Jeapes]] (who also the co-creator of the ''[[EastEnders]]'' [[EastEnders#History|title sequence and theme tune]]"),<ref>http://www2.tv-ark.org.uk/bbctwo/1986_idents.html</ref> the "TWO" was intended as a move for BBC2 to move upmarket. The logo was primarily animated to fade in or out from the background, where it remains static in special idents such as ones specially made for [[Open University]], which has unique idents for the channel.
+
The newly recruited [[BBC Two|BBC2]] controller, [[Alan Yentob]], noticed that the then logo for the channel, which featured 'TWO' in red, green and blue within a white background and the 'O' being white, was affecting the reputation of BBC2 as viewers criticized it. He then decided to commission a worthy successor capable of displaying the personality of the channel, revealing his thoughts in the ''How did they do it?'' episode - about the idents.
â
When Yentob replaced Graeme McDonald as the controller of BBC2 in 1987, he noticed that this former identity was affecting the reputation of the channel as viewers criticized it by calling it "dull" and "worthy" in 1988 after a survey, much to the BBC's executives' surprise.<ref>http://thetvroom.com/bbc-uk/bbc-2-11-01.html</ref> His decision to commision a worthy successor that would display the personality of BBC2 and restore the reputation of the channel led to the concept of the 1991 - 2001 idents (colloquially called "the 2s").<ref>http://www2.tv-ark.org.uk/bbctwo/1991_idents.html</ref>
+
The idents were designed by branding expert [[Martin Lambie-Nairn]], and first aired on the same day as the [[BBC One|BBC1]] virtual [[globe]] [[ident]], also designed by Lambie-Nairn. They were introduced following a survey of viewers by the [[BBC]], which revealed the previous ident for the [[Television channel|channel]] - a 2D computer-generated image of the letters 'TWO' receding into a white background â was considered 'dull' and 'worthy' by viewers.<ref name="ReferenceA">http://www2.tv-ark.org.uk/bbctwo/1991_idents.html</ref>
â
=== Production ===
  â
The idents were designed by branding expert [[Martin Lambie-Nairn]], where the company decided to revert back to the numeral form of "[[2 (number)|2]]" instead of being shown as a word like the "TWO" ident as the channel's earlier idents did show the number as a digit. During development, Lambie-Nairn considered the physical properties of the number "2" and how versatile it can be.
  â
{{quote box |width=30em | bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |align=right|quote="We took this '2', actually, and you think to yourself "Well, there's nothing special about this". But there is something special about this, actually. It's a very distinctive '2'. It's got very sharp bits on it and it's rather nice and fat. The reason we wanted that particular '2' is because we wanted to do things with it. So, you need lots of '2', lots of body on the '2' in order to achieve that."|salign=right |source=Martin Lambie-Nairn<ref>http://www.tv-ark.org.uk/mivana/mediaplayer.php?id=bf143fdc231c264e17fa420639deb254&media=howdotheydothat_bbc2idents&type=mp4</ref>}}
  â
Lambie-Nairn went on to produce a set of idents where a sans-serif '2' would be shown in a variety of forms and environment, usually accompanied with a viridian hue and synthesized bell background music. As the series progressed, some idents displayed neither of these properties such as ''Balloon''.
  â
Some were created by "tricks". ''Paint'' was produced by having the camera rotated 90Â° anti-clockwise as the ident was in fact produced by pouring viridian paint onto the "2" from a height, which would appear that the paint poured sideways as recorded.<ref>http://www.tv-ark.org.uk/mivana/mediaplayer.php?id=bf143fdc231c264e17fa420639deb254&media=howdotheydothat_bbc2idents&type=mp4</ref> ''Water'' had the "2" submerged and the camera at a 45Â° angle where it would be appear that the water was flowing diagonally.<ref>http://www.tv-ark.org.uk/mivana/mediaplayer.php?id=bf143fdc231c264e17fa420639deb254&media=howdotheydothat_bbc2idents&type=mp4</ref> ''Steam'' was filmed in a ring of [[syringes]] suspended over a metallic, steaming "2" whilst dispensing water droplets onto the figure. The camera was protected during this to avoid being damaged by the water.<ref>http://www.tv-ark.org.uk/mivana/mediaplayer.php?id=bf143fdc231c264e17fa420639deb254&media=howdotheydothat_bbc2idents&type=mp4</ref> "Diary" featured paper layers of "2" being peeled off one by one. Due to the difficulty to peel off 10 layers as intended, the first four were looped in different directions to avoid repetition.<ref>http://www.tv-ark.org.uk/mivana/mediaplayer.php?id=bf143fdc231c264e17fa420639deb254&media=howdotheydothat_bbc2idents&type=mp4</ref>
  â
=== Broadcast (1991-1997) ===
  â
The 1991-1997 idents first aired on 16 February 1991 at 6:50am along with the new Open Univeristy symbol, the same day as the [[BBC One|BBC1]] virtual [[globe]] [[ident]] also designed by Lambie-Nairn. The first ident, ''Paint'', coincidentally or not was shown without the BBC [[Digital On-screen Graphic|DOG]]<ref>http://www2.tv-ark.org.uk/bbctwo/1991_idents.html</ref> On that day, the first six idents were shown;
  â
* ''Paint''
  â
* ''Water''
  â
* ''Shadow''
  â
* ''Silk''
  â
* ''Neon''
  â
* ''Paper Cut-Out''
  â
More idents would be included such as "Blade" and "Glass". Holiday idents varied greatly in how many idents were produced. Every [[Christmas]] from 1991 to 1996 had each own ident broadcasted while [[Halloween]] idents only took place in 1992 and [[Valentine's Day]] in 1993. Special idents on historical events were produced such as to commemorate the [[Berlin_Wall#Demolition|demolition of the Berlin Wall]] or to mark the United Nations' Earth Summit|Earth Summit]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]]. The idents were played out by [[LaserDisc]] like the "Virtual Globe" idents, where the format was not widely used but had far greater storage than that of [[VHS]], which was the dominant format at the time, and granted enough storage for the idents' content like the video, sound etc.
  â
The [[Logo of the BBC#1997|new logo for BBC]] in 4 October 1997 marked the end of the 1991-1997 idents as well as many other of the company's channels' identities that featured the 1986 logo. However, many of the idents of this era were retained and aired alongside idents of the 1997-2001 with the 1986 corporate logo being replaced by the current logo as the DOG.
+
=== Production ===
â
+
Lambie-Nairn went on to produce a set of idents where a sans-serif '2' would be shown in a variety of forms and environment, usually accompanied with a viridian hue. Lambie-Nairn then considered the physical properties of the number as BBC2 would then revert back to '2' instead of the English form (Two) as done by its predecessor. {{quote box |width=30em | bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |align=right|quote="We took this '2', actually, and you think to yourself "Well, there's nothing special about this". But there is something special about this, actually. It's a very distinctive '2'. It's very sharp bits on it and it's rather nice and fat. The reason we wanted that particular '2' is because we wanted to do things with it. So, you need lots of '2', lots of body on the '2' in order to achieve that."|salign=right |source=Martin Lambie-Nairn<ref name="HDTDT"/>}}
â
Some idents were withdrawn for particular reasons. ''Crystal Ball'' was the shortest lived ident, having only aired for several weeks and being rarely seen. It is unclear why it was withdrawn. Some have said it was due to similarities of BBC1's Virtual Globe idents, which both involve a glass-like spherical object and have a number shown inside them. Others have said it was because the "2" inside moved around so quickly it was visible for only a fraction of a second.<ref>http://thetvroom.com/bbc-uk/bbc-2-11-01.html</ref> ''Balloon'' was withdrawn before the 1997 rebrand to avoid clashing the [[BBC One 'Balloon' idents]] that would launch after the rebrand. ''Garden'' was withdrawn before the 1997 rebrand. However, the ident was shown from June 2001 to the end of the "1997-2001" idents in November that year to commemorate the 2001 [[Chelsea Flower Show]].
  â   â
=== Reception ===
  â
The idents met with an overwhelmingly positive reception on a survey six months after the original 1988 survey, with negative press having disappeared and calling the new idents as "sophisicated", "amusing" and "witty". BBC also has responded positively to the new use of the "2" symbol, saying that it has a character on its own, especially in stings and bumpers. Yentob declared that the new idents were popular enough to receive [[fan mail]] and that they will renew their contact of the idents.<ref>http://www.tv-ark.org.uk/mivana/mediaplayer.php?id=06164640b113a48301fa53aed7d2e246&media=howdotheydothat_bbc2idents&type=mp4</ref>
  â   â
=== Legacy ===
  â
The 1991-1997 idents (along with its successor) have become among the most popular television branding packages of all time, with the fan mail received and mocks made by fans of the series.<ref>http://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=bbc2+mock+ident&aq=f</ref>. It also was one of the first ident packages with differently themed idents. Though [[MTV]] was the first channel to do so, BBC2's idents made it standard in station identifications for regular use other than for holidays and historical purposes. A sans-serif "2" has remained as BBC2's symbol to this day whilst having a new font by February of 2007.

<div align="justified">''Paint'' featured a white polystyrene '2' on a black & white background, splashed by a blob of [[viridian]] paint which hurtles in horizontally from the right side of the screen. In this ident's soundtrack, the paint is heralded by a steady cymbal crash as it comes into view, reaching a peak upon contact with the '2', followed a two-note resonant sound, symbolic of the dripping paint. This illusion was created by moving the '2' and the camera onto its side by 90 degrees anti-clockwise, to make it appear as though the paint was falling. sideways.<ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vzLkk5pyr3w&feature=related How did they did the BBC2 1991-2001 Idents 1</ref>

Also known as "Fluffy Dog". This ident included a fluffy green '2' whirring, yapping and doing back flips in the manner of a [[toy]] mechanical [[dog]]. The bassline of the audio track is the same as that heard in ''Copper Cut Out''.

Also known as "Fluffy Dog". This ident included a fluffy green '2' whirring, yapping and doing back flips in the manner of a [[toy]] mechanical [[dog]]. The bassline of the audio track is the same as that heard in ''Copper Cut Out''. There was also a short variant where the '2' turned into a scared piece of cotton, but it was only seen during a Monster Night promo from 1998.

Another of the more simple idents, ''Balloon'' featured a silver, [[helium]]-filled [[balloon]] in the shape of a '2' bobbing around gently in a fixed spot. This was withdrawn in 1997 to avoid a clash with the [[BBC One 'Balloon' idents]].<ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Et4xlr_N2lE BBC 1 and BBC 2 Balloons</ref> The music for this sequence usually notably opens with a light, breezy flute that smoothly rises in pitch, but this is because the ident was trimmed in 1996 from it's original start, which can be found [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=if5CQD2FnhU here]. A bongo drum could also be heard supporting the soundtrack.

Line 201: Line 169:
A rarely seen ident that was introduced as one of the 1993 idents, ''Crystal Ball'' was inexplicably dropped after just a few weeks. It featured a [[crystal ball]] rolling across a blue, purple and green background, revealing a distorted image of a '2' as it passed over the middle of the screen. One possible explanation for its removal so quickly after launch was the similarity between it and the [[History of BBC television idents|BBC One 'Virtual Globe' ident]]. It's also rumoured that the ident was pulled due to the decreased visibility of the '2', which was only in view for a split second. A sparse minor chord composition overlaid subtle howling effects, lending a mystical feel. This was the very first ident to be taken out of use.

==Holiday idents==
+
| center;|<div class="center">'''''Aerial'''''</div>
â
Starting in 1974, [[BBC Two]] started to air special idents based on holidays such as [[Christmas]], [[Halloween]] etc. Christmas idents were produced annually (with the exception of 2001 where the channel would have been rebranded upon Christmas of this year). In contrast, Halloween and [[St Valentine's Day]] idents were produced only in the 1991-1997 era.
+
| style="text-align: left; "|<div class="center">4 October 1997 â 19 November 2001</div>
  +
|- 0"
  +
|colspan = "4"|
  +
''Aerial'' featured a viridian '2' with [[antenna (radio)|aerials]] attached to it in a red studio, appearing in random places between flashes of static, before finally appearing in the centre of the screen. The soundtrack is slightly similar to ''Car'' (which aired in 1993 from the previous era), featuring notably prolific use of synthesized bell sounds. This was the first ident to be shown with the then-new "BBC TWO" legend. This was one of the new idents to be added to the line-up after the 1997 revamp along with ''Duck'', ''Paint Pot'', ''Zapper'' and ''Gorilla''.

==Holiday idents==
  +
Starting in 1974, [[BBC Two]] started to air special idents based on holidays such as [[Christmas]], [[Halloween]] etc. Christmas idents were produced annually (with the exception of 2001 where the channel would have been rebranded upon Christmas of this year). In contrast, Halloween and [[St Valentine's Day]] idents were produced only in the 1991-1997 era.
==Special idents==
==Special idents==
â
Various programmes aired on BBC Two in the 1991-2001 period featured specially made idents over the other idents in the series airing at that time.
+
Various programmes aired on BBC Two in the 1991-2001 period featured specially made idents over the other idents in the series airing at that time.
For example, a notable special ident was a series of such in 1998. In 1998, more than 6 idents were created for the [[science fiction]] [[sitcom]], ''[[Red Dwarf]]''.<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EtyTYG9fXwA&feature=related Red Dwarf BBC2 idents montage]</ref>
For example, a notable special ident was a series of such in 1998. In 1998, more than 6 idents were created for the [[science fiction]] [[sitcom]], ''[[Red Dwarf]]''.<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EtyTYG9fXwA&feature=related Red Dwarf BBC2 idents montage]</ref>
â
Below is an incomplete list of some more of these special idents. Those featured are the more notable ones.
+
==Short animations==
  +
During the run of the idents, there were also quick, usually humorous short [[animation]]s shown before the trailers known as 'Stings'. Such examples included a 2-shaped pancake landing in a frying pan, a '2' performing stunts on a bicycle, or a set of spinning plates in the form of the '2'. These were sometimes themed to suit a particular event, such as sport coverage. Examples include a set of snooker balls racked in the '2' shape (of which â like some others â there was more than one variant of the scene). Animations were also often created annually to match the theme of that year's Christmas symbol; for example, a set of short animations featuring [[Wallace and Gromit]] were used during the 1995 Christmas period along with a similarly themed ident.
â
{| class="wikitable" style="width:100%; "
+
Today, these 'sting' animations are not remembered as prominently as most of the idents. They were usually only a few seconds long and, particularly from 1997, the '2' would become a character rather than a symbol, an idea that was carried on for the [[BBC Two]] yellow idents from 2001.
â
